Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSCY9901 - Law and Mental Health","description":"

The course provides an introduction into the development of the Australian legal system; legislation, the administration of the law; rules of evidence; contempt of court; the courts and sentencing in Australia. The course provides an overview of Mental Health Legislation in Australia such as relevant sections in the NSW Mental Health Act 1990 and NSW MH (Criminal Procedures) Act 1990. The course also briefly reviews mental health legislation in New Zealand, U..K., Canada and the United States. A summary of the history of forensic psychiatry in England, and America will be provided; crime and its classification; the measurement of crime; social factors in criminal behaviour; mentally disordered offenders.

This course will provide an understanding of mens rea and the defences to a criminal charge; intent; insanity, diminished responsibility and infanticide: legal aspects criminal responsibility; automatism; some medicolegal consequences of hypoglycaemia; and amnesia. Relevant Australian and 'western' case law will be covered in this course. There will be an introduction into various relevant aspects of criminal responsibility in U.K., Canada, United States and Europe. Topics include: the psychiatrist, psychologist and mental health practitioner as an expert witness; the written mental health / psychiatric court report; mitigation, sentences and prognosis, and; fitness to stand trial and plead, mutism and deafness.

Relevant Australian and 'western' case law will be covered in this course. There will be an introduction into various relevant aspects of criminal responsibility in U.K., Canada, United States and Europe. Topics include: the psychiatrist, psychologist and mental health practitioner as an expert witness; the written mental health / psychiatric court report; mitigation, sentences and prognosis, and; fitness to stand trial and plead, mutism and deafness.

services and how they interact. 5.  Define the role of the staff in the varied institutions and services and relate the various responsibilities of a range of staff within forensic mental health services. 6.  Plan and contribute effectively to a comprehensive mental health service for an area, indicating essential components and roles. 7.  Write a business case for a component of a forensic mental health service. 8.  Recognise the role of clinical corporate governance within forensic mental health The course will cover the functioning and roles of: The Probation and Parole Board; The SORC Advisory Board; Mental Health Review Tribunal; HCC - the Commission; Australian and NZ Royal College of Psychiatrists; The Medical Board and professional conduct; Fitness to practice; Health Department; The Convention on Human Rights. Also covered are the Code of Conduct of: Corrections and the Prison Medical Service; Forensic Mental Health Hospital; Area Health Special Forensic Units and Hospitals; regional secure units and forensic services in UK, Canada, NZ and USA; the forensic aspects of psychiatry in the armed forces; The Probation and Parole Service; special programs such as Sex Offenders, Violence and Drug and Alcohol.

to discuss the complexities of forensic mental health and the management (both clinical and legal) of persons finding themselves involved in the criminal justice system. To reflect on experience os patients/clients in the forensic/correctional setting who may be suffering from a mental illness/disorder and/or personality disorder (or co-morbid disorders). To use the knowledge gained in enriching an approach to everyday practice in a particular field of expertise. To confidently use forensic mental health and legal terms and concepts to explain current ideas about how people with mental illnesses/disorders and personality disorders find themselves involved in the criminal justice system. to identify and analyse mental health problems in the community and in the forensic/correctional setting and make practical, theory-based suggestions for improvements. To understand the complexities and requirements involved in generating court reports for offenders which includes providing an opinion on the possibility of the presence of mental illness, future treatment options and recommendations on how to proceed with a criminal case. Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSCY9912 - Substance Use Problems and Offending","description":"

This course will cover the following material:


  • Understanding the nature of substances including alcohol, amphetamines and methamphetamine, cannabis, opioids and other special groups. 
  • Understanding the bio-psycho-social model of drug use.
  • The psychiatry of substance abuse.
  • Treatment and control of substance abuse.
  • Association between addictive behaviours, substance use and a range of criminal behaviours and violence.
  • Explore the interface between substance use and the Criminal Justice System including NSW Drug Court and therapeutic jurisprudence.
  • Ethics of drug policy and harm minimisation principles.
  • Substance use among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples.
  • Dual Diagnosis treatment strategies and models of care.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c879d9f3db3d1c50eb6b147a3a961983","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Find an example in case law that explores the interface between substance use disorders, mental health and the law. Explore the clinical,legal and ethical issues in that case.   

Word Length: 3000 word essay

Assessment criteria
Your essay will be assessed against the following criteria:
a. comprehensive responses to all aspects of the question
b. evidence of comprehensive research and reading
c. a clearly written and well-structured report
d. accurate and complete referencing using the American Psychological Association
(APA) system
e. adherence to prescribed word length (+/- 10%).

Discuss the principles and initiatives, in policing, legal and health jurisdictions to tackle the issues of crime and violence with particular regard to drug and alcohol use/misuse. Discuss the association between crime, violence and drug and alcohol misuse.

Word Length: 2000 word essay

Assessment criteria

Your report will be assessed against the following criteria:

a. comprehensive responses to all aspects of the question

b. evidence of comprehensive research and reading

c. a clearly written and well-structured report1

d. accurate and complete referencing using the American Psychological Association (APA) system2

e. adherence to prescribed word length (+/- 10%)

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSCY9913","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSCY9913 - Disordered and Criminal Sexual Behaviour","description":"

This course covers the clinical assessment of the paraphilic disorders; a comprehensive understanding of the paraphilic disorders including exhibitionism, sexual sadism, paedophilia, zoophilia, necrophilia, voyeurism, frotteurism; those paraphilic disorders or criminal sexual behaviours involving activities which would bring these individuals to the attention of authorities such as transvestism or cybersex; incest; rape, biological and psycholosocial sex offender treatments; risk assessment and risk management of these offending behaviour or paraphilic disorders.


On completion of this course, students will be able to:


*  Explain the varying definitions, terms and diagnostic criteria of various paraphilic disorders, their sub-categories and types of criminal behaviours.


*  Deploy a sound knowledge of the possible aetiology and clinical presentation of disordered and criminal sexual behaviour when workiing in forensic, social, legal, welfare, psychological, mental health and other professional contexts.


*  Discuss the forensic, legal, social, psychological implications for sex offenders.


*  Use specialist knowledge about assessment, treatment and management in cases involving exhibitionism, sexual sadism, child molestation, fetishism, rape, voyeurism, frotteurism and sexual masochism, amongst other sub-categories.


*  Assess the risk of sexual, violent and criminal re-offending of general sex offenders and different types of sex offenders.


*  Discuss and evaluate a range of sex offender treatments, modalities and management interventions.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"PSCY9917","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"PSCY9917 - Unusual Behaviours and Special Groups","description":"

The aim of this course is to cover rarer psychiatric presentations that confound justice systems. A large part of this knowledge is the ability to apply diverse theoretical models to unusual behaviours in order to understand the psychopathology and motivations behind the behaviours. The broader goal of this knowledge is to inform treatment and management from a range of disciplinary approaches.


The course will cover a diverse range of rarer psychiatric presentations and special groups such as intellectual disability, deception, property crime, arson, kidnapping, feigned illness, and extremism.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2085957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3485d57bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c85957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7085d57bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a885957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e485957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1085957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619e8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Length: 3,000 words

Format: Essay

In focusing on one of the 'special groups' detailed in the course, provide an overview of the unique forensic mental health issues for the group and the implications for assessment, treatment and management (clinical and legal) for individuals belonging to the group.

Assessment criteria

Your essay will be assessed against the following criteria:

a. comprehensive responses to all aspects of the question

b. evidence of comprehensive research and reading

c. a clearly written and well-structured report

d. accurate and complete referencing using the American Psychological Association (APA) system

e. adherence to prescribed word length (+/- 10%).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"2085957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3485d57bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961901","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6c85957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7085d57bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a885957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e485957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619fe","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5885957bdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619ec","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"25","description":"

Length: 3000 words

Format: Essay, in three parts, each part of approximately 1000 words, each part of equal weight.

1. Provide a brief overview of an example case that highlights an unusual behaviour from the course. (Optional: describe a case with an unusual forensic behaviour not covered in the course – please discuss with coordinator before commencing, to confirm if the case is suitable.)

2. Find a reference in the literature to a theoretical construct from neuroscience, psychology, social sciences or law that is relevant to your case example and justify that relevance. (You can use constructs discussed in the course, or others from your reading and knowledge.)

3. Use the theoretical construct to support at least one facet of a management (clinical or legal) approach to the case  (e.g. a biological treatment, psychotherapeutic technique, legal order). If possible, support your choice of management approach with reference to the literature.

Assessment criteria

Your essay will be assessed against the following criteria:

a. comprehensive responses to all aspects of the question

b. evidence of comprehensive research and reading

c. a clearly written and well-structured opinion

d. accurate and complete referencing using the American Psychological Association (APA) system4

e. adherence to prescribed word length (+/- 10%).
